encounters.details: Patient presents for an annual check-up. Reports intermittent shortness of breath and wheezing, especially with exercise.
encounters.comparison: No history of respiratory issues noted in previous records.
encounters.findings: Lungs have mild expiratory wheezes. Spirometry shows a reversible obstructive pattern consistent with asthma.
encounters.impression: New diagnosis of mild persistent asthma. Prescribed a daily inhaled corticosteroid (Fluticasone) and a rescue inhaler (Albuterol).

encounters.details: Follow-up visit to assess asthma control after starting new medications.
encounters.comparison: Patient was newly diagnosed with asthma and started on inhalers.
encounters.findings: Patient reports significant improvement in symptoms and has only used her rescue inhaler twice. Lung exam is clear.
encounters.impression: Asthma is well-controlled on the current regimen. Continue treatment and follow up in 6 months.

encounters.details: Patient complains of a productive cough and chest congestion for five days, following a cold.
encounters.comparison: Patient has a history of asthma.
encounters.findings: Coarse rhonchi are heard over the large airways, but no wheezing. Chest X-ray is clear.
encounters.impression: Acute Bronchitis. Advised supportive care, including rest, fluids, and use of her Albuterol inhaler as needed for any associated wheezing.

encounters.details: Patient fell onto his outstretched right hand while playing soccer. Presents with severe wrist pain and deformity.
encounters.comparison: No prior injuries to the right wrist.
encounters.findings: Visible deformity of the right wrist. X-ray confirms a displaced, intra-articular distal radius fracture.
encounters.impression: Complex distal radius fracture. Orthopedic consultation obtained. Patient underwent closed reduction and splinting in the ER.

encounters.details: Orthopedic follow-up for right wrist fracture.
encounters.comparison: Initial X-rays showed a displaced fracture.
encounters.findings: Repeat X-rays show good alignment of the fracture fragments within the splint.
encounters.impression: Stable fracture alignment. Patient will be placed in a cast and will follow up in 2 weeks. Continue to elevate the hand and manage pain.

encounters.details: Follow-up for cast removal and assessment.
encounters.comparison: Patient has been in a cast for 8 weeks.
encounters.findings: Cast removed. X-rays show the fracture has healed. There is significant stiffness in the wrist and fingers.
encounters.impression: Healed fracture. Referred to occupational therapy to regain range of motion and strength.

encounters.details: Final occupational therapy session.
encounters.comparison: Initial evaluation showed a 50% deficit in wrist range of motion.
encounters.findings: Patient has made excellent progress with therapy. Range of motion is now nearly full, and grip strength has returned to 90% of the contralateral side.
encounters.impression: Discharged from therapy. Continue home exercise program.

encounters.details: Patient referred for evaluation of painful, swollen joints in her hands and feet for the past 4 months.
encounters.comparison: Previously healthy with no joint issues.
encounters.findings: Symmetrical synovitis of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. Labs show positive rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies.
encounters.impression: Seropositive Rheumatoid Arthritis. Started on Methotrexate and a short course of Prednisone.

encounters.details: Follow-up to assess response to DMARD therapy.
encounters.comparison: Patient had active synovitis in multiple joints.
encounters.findings: Patient reports significant improvement in pain and swelling. Prednisone has been tapered off. No new joint involvement.
encounters.impression: Good response to Methotrexate. Continue current dose and monitor for side effects.

encounters.details: Routine follow-up for RA.
encounters.comparison: Previous visit showed good disease control.
encounters.findings: Patient is in clinical remission with no tender or swollen joints. Inflammatory markers are normal.
encounters.impression: Rheumatoid Arthritis in remission. Continue Methotrexate and monitor labs quarterly.

encounters.details: Patient presents for his 5-year well-child check.
encounters.comparison: Developmentally on track at his 4-year check.
encounters.findings: Growth and development are appropriate for age. Physical exam is normal. Vaccinations are up to date.
encounters.impression: Healthy 5-year-old. Discussed school readiness and safety.

encounters.details: Patient has a 2-day history of fever and right ear pain.
encounters.comparison: One previous ear infection at age 2.
encounters.findings: Otoscopy reveals a bulging, erythematous right tympanic membrane with loss of landmarks.
encounters.impression: Acute Otitis Media of the right ear. Prescribed a 10-day course of Amoxicillin.

encounters.details: Patient has a runny nose, cough, and low-grade fever.
encounters.comparison: History of a recent ear infection.
encounters.findings: Lungs are clear. Ears are non-infected. Throat is mildly red.
encounters.impression: Common cold. Advised supportive care.

encounters.details: Routine screening colonoscopy for a patient of average risk.
encounters.comparison: This is the patient's first colonoscopy.
encounters.findings: A 1.5 cm sessile polyp was found in the sigmoid colon and was completely removed via polypectomy.
encounters.impression: Sigmoid colon polyp. The specimen was sent to pathology.

encounters.details: Follow-up to discuss pathology results from colonoscopy.
encounters.comparison: A 1.5 cm polyp was removed.
encounters.findings: Pathology report confirms the polyp was a tubular adenoma with no high-grade dysplasia.
encounters.impression: Benign but pre-cancerous polyp removed. Due to the size of the adenoma, a repeat surveillance colonoscopy is recommended in 3 years.

encounters.details: Routine annual exam. Patient reports vaginal dryness and discomfort.
encounters.comparison: Last year's exam was normal.
encounters.findings: Pelvic exam reveals pale, thin vaginal mucosa consistent with atrophic changes.
encounters.impression: Atrophic vaginitis. Discussed treatment options, and the patient was prescribed a topical estrogen cream.

encounters.details: Patient self-referred for evaluation of a 6-month history of low mood, anhedonia, and poor sleep.
encounters.comparison: No prior psychiatric history.
encounters.findings: Patient meets DSM-5 criteria for a moderate episode of Major Depressive Disorder based on the PHQ-9 score and clinical interview.
encounters.impression: Major Depressive Disorder. Started on an SSRI (Sertraline) and referred for weekly psychotherapy.

encounters.details: Medication management follow-up.
encounters.comparison: Patient was started on Sertraline one month ago.
encounters.findings: Patient reports a gradual improvement in mood and energy levels. He is tolerating the medication well and attending therapy.
encounters.impression: Positive initial response to treatment. Continue Sertraline at the current dose and follow up in 2 months.

encounters.details: Follow-up visit to assess continued progress.
encounters.comparison: Previous visit showed partial response.
encounters.findings: Patient's PHQ-9 score is now in the mild range. He reports significant functional improvement and is benefiting from therapy.
encounters.impression: Good response to combined treatment. Continue current plan.

encounters.details: Patient presents with seasonal complaints of sneezing, nasal congestion, and itchy eyes.
encounters.comparison: Experiences similar symptoms every spring.
encounters.findings: Nasal mucosa is pale and boggy. Eyes are injected.
encounters.impression: Seasonal Allergic Rhinitis. Recommended an over-the-counter antihistamine and a nasal steroid spray.

encounters.details: Patient developed hives and intense itching over her trunk and arms after eating at a new seafood restaurant.
encounters.comparison: No known allergies.
encounters.findings: Widespread, blanching, erythematous plaques (wheals) are present on the skin. No signs of anaphylaxis.
encounters.impression: Acute Urticaria, likely due to a food allergy. Treated with an injection of Diphenhydramine and a prescription for oral Cetirizine.

encounters.details: Allergy consultation following an episode of acute urticaria.
encounters.comparison: The suspected trigger was a seafood meal.
encounters.findings: Skin prick testing is strongly positive for shrimp and crab.
encounters.impression: Confirmed IgE-mediated allergy to shellfish. Patient was counseled on strict avoidance, and an epinephrine auto-injector was prescribed.

encounters.details: Annual physical exam.
encounters.comparison: New diagnosis of shellfish allergy since last visit.
encounters.findings: Exam is normal. Patient verbalizes understanding of her allergy and how to use her epinephrine auto-injector.
encounters.impression: Healthy young woman. Reinforced allergy action plan.

encounters.details: Patient evaluated for recurrent episodes of right upper quadrant pain after eating fatty foods.
encounters.comparison: Pain has been occurring for 6 months.
encounters.findings: Abdominal ultrasound confirms the presence of multiple gallstones within the gallbladder, without signs of acute inflammation.
encounters.impression: Symptomatic Cholelithiasis. Patient is a candidate for elective cholecystectomy.

encounters.details: Pre-operative history and physical for upcoming laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
encounters.comparison: Patient has a history of well-controlled hypertension.
encounters.findings: Exam is normal. EKG and labs are unremarkable. Blood pressure is well-controlled.
encounters.impression: Patient is cleared for surgery.

encounters.details: Patient underwent an uncomplicated laparoscopic removal of the gallbladder.
encounters.comparison: Pre-operative diagnosis was cholelithiasis.
encounters.findings: The procedure was successful. The patient tolerated it well and was discharged home the same day.
encounters.impression: Successful cholecystectomy. Follow up in 2 weeks.

encounters.details: Routine post-operative check.
encounters.comparison: Patient is 2 weeks post-op.
encounters.findings: Incisions are clean, dry, and intact. Patient's abdominal pain has completely resolved, and he is tolerating a regular diet.
encounters.impression: Excellent recovery. No further follow-up needed.

encounters.details: Patient seeking treatment for persistent comedonal and inflammatory acne on her face and back.
encounters.comparison: Over-the-counter treatments have failed.
encounters.findings: Numerous open and closed comedones, papules, and pustules are present on the face and upper back.
encounters.impression: Moderate Acne Vulgaris. Prescribed a combination of topical tretinoin and oral doxycycline.

encounters.details: Follow-up for acne treatment.
encounters.comparison: Patient had moderate inflammatory acne at the initial visit.
encounters.findings: There is a significant reduction in inflammatory lesions. Comedones are still present but improved.
encounters.impression: Good response to treatment. Discontinue doxycycline and continue with topical tretinoin. Add a topical benzoyl peroxide wash.

encounters.details: Patient requested removal of a mole on her shoulder for cosmetic reasons.
encounters.comparison: The mole has been present since childhood and is unchanged.
encounters.findings: A 4mm, symmetrical, uniformly brown nevus is present on the left shoulder. No suspicious features.
encounters.impression: Shave removal of a benign-appearing nevus was performed under local anesthesia. The specimen was sent for pathology as a precaution.

encounters.details: Patient presents for an annual exam. Reports a chronic productive cough and increasing shortness of breath on exertion.
encounters.comparison: Patient has a 50-pack-year smoking history.
encounters.findings: Decreased breath sounds and a prolonged expiratory phase. Chest X-ray shows hyperinflation. Spirometry confirms moderate, non-reversible obstruction.
encounters.impression: Moderate COPD. Counseled on smoking cessation. Started on a long-acting bronchodilator (Tiotropium).

encounters.details: Follow-up for COPD management.
encounters.comparison: Patient was recently diagnosed and started on Tiotropium.
encounters.findings: Patient reports a noticeable improvement in his baseline shortness of breath. He has successfully quit smoking.
encounters.impression: Good response to initial therapy and smoking cessation. Continue Tiotropium and schedule for pulmonary rehabilitation.

encounters.details: Patient presents with a 3-day history of worsening cough, increased sputum production, and increased shortness of breath.
encounters.comparison: His baseline COPD symptoms were previously stable.
encounters.findings: Patient is in mild respiratory distress with wheezing. Oxygen saturation is 91% on room air.
encounters.impression: Acute exacerbation of COPD, likely triggered by a viral infection. Treated with oral steroids, nebulized bronchodilators, and a course of antibiotics.

encounters.details: Follow-up after a recent COPD exacerbation.
encounters.comparison: Patient was treated in urgent care 10 days ago.
encounters.findings: Patient's symptoms have returned to his baseline. He has completed the course of steroids and antibiotics.
encounters.impression: Resolution of the acute exacerbation. Reinforced the importance of the action plan and added a combination LABA/LAMA inhaler to his daily regimen.
